#### 
Marine Bronze Star recipient from iconic Fallujah photo attacked at a D.C. McDonald's
=====================================================================================
By Jeff Schogol
 Feb 16, 2016
!:quality(70)/cloudfront-us-east-1.images.arcpublishing.com/archetype/56OD67PEUBBGROBV7OQCTPEPZ4.jpg)
Police in Washington, D.C., are looking for at least four people in connection with the assault and robbery of a veteran former Marine sergeant and recipient of the Bronze Star with "V" recipient device, who was one of two Marines who helped carry then-1st Sgt. Bradley Kasal out of Fallujah’s infamous "Hell House."
"Coming back here and being attacked by the people that we're supposed to protect – it's kind of ironic, I guess," Christopher Marquez told Marine Corps Times.
"It's very ironic: being attacked by the people you're there to serve," Christopher Marquez told Marine Corps Times.
Christopher Marquez, who served in the Marine Corps from 2003 to 2011, told police he was assaulted on Friday around 10:30 p.m. eb. 12 while eating at a McDonald's, according to a Metropolitan Police Department report of the incident. The suspects took Marquez’ wallet, identification, credit cards, debit card and about $400 in cash, the report says.
"When we’re in the military, we’re there for our country," Marquez told Marine Corps Times. "...It’s very ironic: being attacked by the people you're \ there to serve."
Marquez said told Marine Corps Times that he believes the attack was racially motivated. He remembers being accosted at the McDonald's in Washington's Chinatown neighborhood by five people between 16 and 21 years old. Most were men or boys. One may have been female.
"The kids were asking me if I think that black lives mattered," Marquez said on Monday. "I was ignoring them, just because I felt intimidated. I felt how they approached me, it was very hostile. I felt they were really trying to intimidate me and just trying to start a confrontation with me."
The police report does not include a description of the four people involved with the incident, which was first reported by . One of the suspects...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: As a reputable publication that focuses on Marine Corps news, Marine Corps Times is generally considered a reliable source for military-related stories, events, and veteran affairs. The site is known for journalistic standards and often features articles that are well-researched and accurate. However, it is less known for covering broader news stories outside military context, which slightly limits its broader news credibility.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source provides a detailed account of the incident, including Marquez's perspective on the alleged racial motivations of the attack and the description of the assailants. It directly correlates with the question regarding corroborating evidence and eyewitness accounts since Marquez himself is an eyewitness and offers a narrative that includes the actions and words of the suspected assailants in connection with the claim.

Former US marine attacked at McDonald's. Was it racially motivated?
===================================================================
Christopher Marquez, a former US Marine, says the assault last Friday night at a McDonald's in Washington, D.C., came after a group of young men asked him whether 'black lives matter.'
    !
|
KGTV - San Diego, CA
Former US Marine Christopher Marquez says he was attacked at a McDonald's in Washington, D.C.
Loading...
*   By  Staff
February 18, 2016
A former US Marine who was assaulted at a McDonald’s in downtown Washington, D.C., last Friday says the attack was racially motivated, but questions persist about motivations for the assault, local police said this week.
Christopher Marquez, who served in Iraq and  and now attends American University,  that the attack, which he said was unprovoked, occurred after several black teenagers and young men asked him whether “black lives matter” and then called him racist.
According to a D.C. police report, Mr. Marquez, who is Hispanic, told officers that one young man hit him in the face with a handgun and stole bank cards and his wallet, which had $400 inside, the Post reports. Dustin Sternbeck, the chief D.C. police spokesman told the Post that detectives were reviewing surveillance video of the incident but it wasn’t immediately clear what it showed.
A  in the conservative website the Daily Caller based primarily on Marquez’s account of the assault led to several reports that concluded that the men involved in the assault were affiliated with the Black Lives Matter movement.
But D.C. police told the Post and the  they could not verify the identities of the men or the motive described by Marquez. One officer told Snopes that there was no indication that any of the individuals in the altercation were involved with or mentioned Black Lives Matter.
Snopes also noted that Marquez had told the Daily Caller his memory of the incident was fuzzy after sustaining a blow to the back of the head and that he said some details of the incident were provided to him the next day by...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Christian Science Monitor is known for its balanced and in-depth reporting. It has a strong reputation for journalistic integrity and often fact-checks its information rigorously. CS Monitor has won multiple journalism awards and is generally seen as a reliable source of news. Their rigorous editorial standards help in detecting and exposing fake news effectively.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article presents both Marquez's claims about the racial motivation of the incident and discusses the ambiguity surrounding the claims about the attackers being affiliated with Black Lives Matter. It factors in the police's inability to verify the suspects' identities related to the movement, thereby providing a balanced view relevant to the query about corroboration and eyewitness accounts.

Breaking News
2 teens arrested in attack on Marine at D.C. McDonald’s
=======================================================
Two teens have been arrested in connection to the assault and robbery of a veteran Marine sergeant, D.C. police said.
! !
Credit: Photo courtesy of Christopher Marquez
Veteran Marine Sgt. Christopher Marquez, shown here in South Korea, was recently assaulted at a McDonald's in Washington, D.C. Marquez said he believes the incident was racially motivated.
Author: WUSA-TV (Washington, D.C.)
Published: 2:10 PM CST February 23, 2016
Updated: 2:11 PM CST February 23, 2016
]
WASHINGTON -- Two teens have been arrested in connection to the assault and robbery of a veteran Marine sergeant, D.C. police said.
Police said one 17-year-old male and one 17-year-old female were involved in the attack. The male was charged with aggravated assault and the female was charged with robbery.
Christopher Marquez, a Bronze Star recipient, who served in the Marine Corps from 2003 to 2011, told police he . Police later  of the assault.
Marquez said he believes the February 12th attack was racially motivated.
“The kids were asking me if I think that black lives mattered,” Marquez told the _Marine Corps Times_. “I was ignoring them, just because I felt intimidated. I felt how they approached me, it was very hostile. I felt they were really trying to intimidate me and just trying to start a confrontation with me.”
One of the suspects allegedly hit Marquez with a gun after calling him a racist, according to a police report.
The...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: KARE 11 is a local news station in Minnesota with a decent reputation for local reporting. However, as it often covers local news events primarily, their overall reach and rigor in fact-checking compared to national outlets may be less thorough. While they provide good coverage for their region, their effectiveness in addressing broader national issues can vary.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source provides updates on the arrests made in connection to the assault, affirming that there were indeed individuals involved. However, it does not present firsthand accounts or corroborate the specifics of the racial motivations alleged by Marquez, which reduces its direct relevance to the query.

WASHINGTON -- Two teens have been arrested in 
Police said one 17-year-old male and one 17-year-old female were involved in the attack. The male was charged with aggravated assault and the female was charged with robbery.
Christopher Marquez, a Bronze Star recipient, who served in the Marine Corps from 2003 to 2011, told police he was assaulted while eating at a McDonald's.
Marquez said he believes the February 12th attack was racially motivated.
“The kids were asking me if I think that black lives mattered,”  “I was ignoring them, just because I felt intimidated. I felt how they approached me, it was very hostile. I felt they were really trying to intimidate me and just trying to start a confrontation with me.”

Breaking News
Caught on Camera: Teens attack Marine at DC McDonald's
======================================================
Surveillance video has been released in the assault and robbery of a veteran Marine sergeant at a McDonald's in D.C.
! !
Surveillance video has been released in the assault and robbery of a veteran Marine sergeant at a McDonald's in D.C. (Photo: DC Police)
Author: WUSA9 (USA Today , KTHV)
Published: 4:55 PM CST February 18, 2016
Updated: 4:56 PM CST February 18, 2016
]
_WARNING: Video may be considered graphic to some viewers. Please use your discretion._
WASHINGTON (WUSA9/USA TODAY) -- Surveillance video has been released in the assault and robbery of a veteran Marine sergeant at a McDonald's in D.C.
Police are looking for at least four people in connection with the assault and robbery of Christopher Marquez. Marquez is a Bronze Star recipient, who was one of two Marines who helped carry then-1st Sgt. Bradley Kasal out of Fallujah’s infamous “Hell House”, according to USA Today.
Marquez, who served in the Marine Corps from 2003 to 2011, told police he was assaulted on Friday around 10:30 p.m. while eating at a McDonald's, according to a Metropolitan Police Department report.
Marquez said he believes the attack was racially motivated. USA Today says he remembers being accosted at the McDonald's in Washington's Chinatown neighborhood by five people between 16 and 21-years-old. Most were men or boys. One may have been female.
“The kids were asking me if I think that black lives mattered,” Marquez told USA Today on Monday. “I was ignoring them, just because I felt intimidated....[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: WFAA is a local news station based in Dallas, Texas, that covers both national and local news. While generally reliable for local news, the quality of reporting can be inconsistent when it comes to national topics. The site does rely on typical broadcast news standards which may not always meet the rigorous fact-checking seen in larger national news organizations.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source mentions the surveillance footage of the assault and acknowledges the details Marquez provides about the incident. While it adds context in terms of the visual evidence, it does not directly provide corroborating witness accounts outside of Marquez's narrative.

website_content.content:
This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten,
      or redistributed. ©2024 FOX News Network, LLC. All rights reserved.
      Quotes displayed in real-time or delayed by at least 15 minutes. Market data provided by
      Factset. Powered and implemented by

      Legal Statement. Mutual Fund and ETF data provided by
      Refinitiv Lipper.
    
Iraq was veteran Christopher Marquez was attacked and robbed by a group of five people
Authorities worked Wednesday to identify at least four people who attacked and robbed a decorated former Marine at a Washington, D.C. McDonald’s, leaving him in the restaurant unconscious.
Christopher Marquez, 30, an Iraq War vet, told the Washington Post he was eating in a back corner of the restaurant on Friday when a group of teens and young men approached his table.
"They saw me and crowded around ... and they started asking me if I believed black lives matter,” Marquez told the paper. “I was ignoring them, then they started calling me racist."
At that point, Marquez said he left the McDonald's, but was knocked unconscious by a blow to his head. When he came to, his pants were ripped and his wallet, which contained $400 in cash, three credit cards and VA medical card among other items, was missing.
DeAnthony Mason, manager of the McDonald’s, reviewed security footage and told Marquez that he was hit on the side of the head before the other teens converged on his body to take his belongings, The Daily Caller reports.
Credit card transactions reviewed by The Daily Caller revealed that Marquez’s cards later were charged more than $115 at a liquor store, Five Guys and a Walmart.
The teens involved in the attack were being sought by police for a previous incident, Mason said, according to Marquez.
But the D.C. Metropolitan Police told FoxNews.com Wednesday that they are still working to identify the four people in the video.
According to the Daily Caller, which first reported the incident, Marquez was able to take a cab back to his apartment, where building employees called police. He was treated at George Washington University Hospital for head trauma.
Marquez served in the Marine Corps from 2003 to 2011. He was awarded the Bronze Star with combat distinguishing device for valor during the battle for Fallujah...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Fox News has a significant national presence and provides a wide array of news coverage. However, it is often criticized for bias and for sensationalizing news stories, affected by its political affiliations. While it has substantial reach and audience trust among certain demographics, its commitment to objective reporting may be questioned, which can limit its credibility in detecting and exposing fake news.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence includes a comprehensive account of Marquez's experience, detailing not only the attack but also his aftermath and claims regarding the assailants’ actions and intentions. It supports Marquez's assertions, thereby reinforcing its relevance to evaluating the validity of the claims.

metatags.dc.description: Police made two arrests Monday following the assault earlier this month of a decorated Marine outside a fast-food restaurant in Washington, D.C.
metatags.twitter:title: Police arrest 2 for assault on 'Hell House' Marine
metatags.og:title: Police arrest 2 for assault on 'Hell House' Marine
metatags.title: Police arrest 2 for assault on 'Hell House' Marine

metatags.twitter:description: Police made two arrests Monday following the assault earlier this month of a decorated Marine outside a fast-food restaurant in Washington, D.C.
metatags.dc.title: Police arrest 2 for assault on 'Hell House' Marine

website_content.content:
Sgt. Chris Marquez, left, and Cpl. Dane Shaffer, two of the three Marines the "Hell House" statue is based on, help unveil the new monument at the Warrior Hope and Care Center at Camp Lejeune, March 8, 2013. (U.S. Marines)
			
WASHINGTON — Police made two arrests Monday following the assault earlier this month of a decorated Marine outside a fast-food restaurant in Washington, D.C.
 A 17-year-old male was charged with aggravated assault and a 17-year-old female was charged with robbery. Both are from Washington and were not named by police due to their age.
 A third person was suspected in the Feb. 12 attack, which victim Christopher Marquez said was racially motivated. Police said the investigation is continuing.
 “The kids were asking me if I think that black lives mattered,” Marquez told USA Today this month. “I was ignoring them, just because I felt intimidated. I felt how they approached me, it was very hostile. I felt they were really trying to intimidate me and just trying to start a confrontation with me.”
 A surveillance video released by police last week shows a black male assailant in a white tank top punch Marquez in the head from behind as Marquez walked out of a McDonald’s on E Street across from FBI headquarters, according to police.
 Marquez, 30, is a Bronze Star with “V” device recipient who fought in Fallujah, Iraq, in 2004 and served until 2011.
 After being punched, Marquez fell to the ground where he was robbed by the female suspect and then kicked in the head, police said.
 Marquez was one of three Marines in an iconic photo taken during the second battle of Fallujah. He was photographed carrying a fellow Marine whose uniform is blood-soaked from a wound during the so-called Hell House battle during which one Marine was killed and 10 were wounded.
tritten.travis@stripes.com Twitter: @Travis_Tritten

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Stars and Stripes is a well-regarded publication that focuses on military news and issues affecting service members and their families. It is known for detailed investigative reporting and maintaining high journalistic standards, making it a credible source for military-related news. However, like Marine Corps Times, its focus is more niche.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source reaffirms the arrests made in connection to the incident while mentioning the racial claims. Additionally, it highlights Marquez's viewpoint, aligning it with the specifics of the event but lacking deeper corroborating evidence.
